comment: This pawn sacrifice was unjustified by White. With best play, black should win.

moves: 1. b4 e5 2. Nc3 Bxb4 3. Bb2 Nf6 4. e4 Nc6 5. Nf3 O-O 6. g3 Nd4
comment:
Black could've won another pawn
using a tactical motif called, "Removing the Defender". 6. ... Bxc3 7. Bxc3
Nxe4. White cannot take on e5, or he will lose at least a piece because of the
pin on the e-line.

moves: 1. b4 e5 2. Nc3 Bxb4 3. Bb2 Nf6 4. e4 Nc6 5. Nf3 O-O 6. g3 Nd4 7. Bg2 d6 8. O-O Bg4 9. h3 Nxf3+ 10. Bxf3 Bxf3
comment:
Why not win
the pawn on h3? White can't trap the Bishop with 11. g4 since by taking the
pawn, the bishop would also threaten the rook at f1. This concept is known as
gaining a tempo.

moves: 1. b4 e5 2. Nc3 Bxb4 3. Bb2 Nf6 4. e4 Nc6 5. Nf3 O-O 6. g3 Nd4 7. Bg2 d6 8. O-O Bg4 9. h3 Nxf3+ 10. Bxf3 Bxf3 11. Qxf3 b5
comment:
?! Definitely dubious. This makes black's pawn
structure slightly weaker. Why not solidfy central control with ...c6, Re8,
with a ...d5 expansion? Remember, when ahead in material, trade pieces, not
pawns.

moves: 1. b4 e5 2. Nc3 Bxb4 3. Bb2 Nf6 4. e4 Nc6 5. Nf3 O-O 6. g3 Nd4 7. Bg2 d6 8. O-O Bg4 9. h3 Nxf3+ 10. Bxf3 Bxf3 11. Qxf3 b5 12. Nxb5 Bxd2
comment:
As a result of this interchange, white has 3 pawn
islands, black has 2. A pawn island is a group of pawns separated by open
files. This should give black a slight endgame advantage. The reason that
fewer pawn islands is better, is that they don't need pieces to defend them
(they can defend each other).

moves: 1. b4 e5 2. Nc3 Bxb4 3. Bb2 Nf6 4. e4 Nc6 5. Nf3 O-O 6. g3 Nd4 7. Bg2 d6 8. O-O Bg4 9. h3 Nxf3+ 10. Bxf3 Bxf3 11. Qxf3 b5 12. Nxb5 Bxd2 13. Rad1 Rb8 14. Rxd2 Rxb5 15. Ba3 Ra5
comment:
Remember your heavy pieces (Queen, rooks) want to double on the open file
(column). Therefore, Qb8 would be quite strong, to establish b-file control.
Black could follow-up with ...Qb7 (pressuring white's e-pawn), ...Rfb8, and/or
Rb1 with a definite edge for black.

moves: 1. b4 e5 2. Nc3 Bxb4 3. Bb2 Nf6 4. e4 Nc6 5. Nf3 O-O 6. g3 Nd4 7. Bg2 d6 8. O-O Bg4 9. h3 Nxf3+ 10. Bxf3 Bxf3 11. Qxf3 b5 12. Nxb5 Bxd2 13. Rad1 Rb8 14. Rxd2 Rxb5 15. Ba3 Ra5 16. Rd3 Qb8
comment:
...Qa8! (pressuring white's
e-pawn again) is quite strong... white would have to be tied down with Re1,
then Rb8, followed by the killer shot ...d5 (white can't take because ...e4
would fork white's queen and rook).

moves: 1. b4 e5 2. Nc3 Bxb4 3. Bb2 Nf6 4. e4 Nc6 5. Nf3 O-O 6. g3 Nd4 7. Bg2 d6 8. O-O Bg4 9. h3 Nxf3+ 10. Bxf3 Bxf3 11. Qxf3 b5 12. Nxb5 Bxd2 13. Rad1 Rb8 14. Rxd2 Rxb5 15. Ba3 Ra5 16. Rd3 Qb8 17. Rb3 Qc8 18. Qc3 Ra6 19. Qc4 Nd7
comment:
The knight was already good on f6. Better was to oppose white's control of the
b-file with ...Rb6. This would also free your queen from defense of the rook
on a6, so ...Qxh3 is a real threat.

moves: 1. b4 e5 2. Nc3 Bxb4 3. Bb2 Nf6 4. e4 Nc6 5. Nf3 O-O 6. g3 Nd4 7. Bg2 d6 8. O-O Bg4 9. h3 Nxf3+ 10. Bxf3 Bxf3 11. Qxf3 b5 12. Nxb5 Bxd2 13. Rad1 Rb8 14. Rxd2 Rxb5 15. Ba3 Ra5 16. Rd3 Qb8 17. Rb3 Qc8 18. Qc3 Ra6 19. Qc4 Nd7 20. Rfb1 Rb6 21. f4
comment:
This is a dubious
line opening by white. There are too many hanging white pawns, plus this opens
up White's king considerably.

moves: 1. b4 e5 2. Nc3 Bxb4 3. Bb2 Nf6 4. e4 Nc6 5. Nf3 O-O 6. g3 Nd4 7. Bg2 d6 8. O-O Bg4 9. h3 Nxf3+ 10. Bxf3 Bxf3 11. Qxf3 b5 12. Nxb5 Bxd2 13. Rad1 Rb8 14. Rxd2 Rxb5 15. Ba3 Ra5 16. Rd3 Qb8 17. Rb3 Qc8 18. Qc3 Ra6 19. Qc4 Nd7 20. Rfb1 Rb6 21. f4 Rxb3 22. axb3 Nb6 23. Qf1 exf4 24. Qxf4
comment:
This is obviously an oversight by white. White had to play gxf4, and if black
tries to open things up with ..f5, then e5 gives White a fighting chance.

moves: 1. b4 e5 2. Nc3 Bxb4 3. Bb2 Nf6 4. e4 Nc6 5. Nf3 O-O 6. g3 Nd4 7. Bg2 d6 8. O-O Bg4 9. h3 Nxf3+ 10. Bxf3 Bxf3 11. Qxf3 b5 12. Nxb5 Bxd2 13. Rad1 Rb8 14. Rxd2 Rxb5 15. Ba3 Ra5 16. Rd3 Qb8 17. Rb3 Qc8 18. Qc3 Ra6 19. Qc4 Nd7 20. Rfb1 Rb6 21. f4 Rxb3 22. axb3 Nb6 23. Qf1 exf4 24. Qxf4 Qxh3 25. Rd1 Nc8
comment:
Why not ...Nd7? The post on e5 would be very strong for black.
Remember, if you can, try to centralize your knights... they drive a wedge in
your opponent's position.

moves: 1. b4 e5 2. Nc3 Bxb4 3. Bb2 Nf6 4. e4 Nc6 5. Nf3 O-O 6. g3 Nd4 7. Bg2 d6 8. O-O Bg4 9. h3 Nxf3+ 10. Bxf3 Bxf3 11. Qxf3 b5 12. Nxb5 Bxd2 13. Rad1 Rb8 14. Rxd2 Rxb5 15. Ba3 Ra5 16. Rd3 Qb8 17. Rb3 Qc8 18. Qc3 Ra6 19. Qc4 Nd7 20. Rfb1 Rb6 21. f4 Rxb3 22. axb3 Nb6 23. Qf1 exf4 24. Qxf4 Qxh3 25. Rd1 Nc8 26. e5 Rd8 27. exd6 cxd6 28. Bxd6
comment:
? This loses.
White's bishop is much stronger than the knight at c8, plus when behind in
material trade pawns, not pieces. Since black's d-pawn is pinned, c4 looks
likes White's best chance. Now black can win a piece with ...Qe6. Remember
attack pinned pieces! You might win them.

moves: 1. b4 e5 2. Nc3 Bxb4 3. Bb2 Nf6 4. e4 Nc6 5. Nf3 O-O 6. g3 Nd4 7. Bg2 d6 8. O-O Bg4 9. h3 Nxf3+ 10. Bxf3 Bxf3 11. Qxf3 b5 12. Nxb5 Bxd2 13. Rad1 Rb8 14. Rxd2 Rxb5 15. Ba3 Ra5 16. Rd3 Qb8 17. Rb3 Qc8 18. Qc3 Ra6 19. Qc4 Nd7 20. Rfb1 Rb6 21. f4 Rxb3 22. axb3 Nb6 23. Qf1 exf4 24. Qxf4 Qxh3 25. Rd1 Nc8 26. e5 Rd8 27. exd6 cxd6 28. Bxd6 Nxd6 29. c4 Nb7 30. Rxd8+ Nxd8 31. Qb8 Qd7 32. b4 Kf8 33. c5 Ke8 34. b5 a5
comment:
This is not right. ..Qd4+, then ...
Qxc5 would force white to resign. Notice ...Qxc5 defends a7, covers e5 against
potential checks by the white queen, and helps restrict white's b-pawn. Why
does the black queen do so much? Because it's centralized! I can't emphasize
the importance of this enough.

moves: 1. b4 e5 2. Nc3 Bxb4 3. Bb2 Nf6 4. e4 Nc6 5. Nf3 O-O 6. g3 Nd4 7. Bg2 d6 8. O-O Bg4 9. h3 Nxf3+ 10. Bxf3 Bxf3 11. Qxf3 b5 12. Nxb5 Bxd2 13. Rad1 Rb8 14. Rxd2 Rxb5 15. Ba3 Ra5 16. Rd3 Qb8 17. Rb3 Qc8 18. Qc3 Ra6 19. Qc4 Nd7 20. Rfb1 Rb6 21. f4 Rxb3 22. axb3 Nb6 23. Qf1 exf4 24. Qxf4 Qxh3 25. Rd1 Nc8 26. e5 Rd8 27. exd6 cxd6 28. Bxd6 Nxd6 29. c4 Nb7 30. Rxd8+ Nxd8 31. Qb8 Qd7 32. b4 Kf8 33. c5 Ke8 34. b5 a5 35. b6
comment:
White had much stronger, c6! This
threatens c6-c7-c8(Q). Black would be forced to take the draw by perpetual
check! Remember, 2 connected passed pawns are very strong. White's move allows
a light-squared blockade by black.

moves: 1. b4 e5 2. Nc3 Bxb4 3. Bb2 Nf6 4. e4 Nc6 5. Nf3 O-O 6. g3 Nd4 7. Bg2 d6 8. O-O Bg4 9. h3 Nxf3+ 10. Bxf3 Bxf3 11. Qxf3 b5 12. Nxb5 Bxd2 13. Rad1 Rb8 14. Rxd2 Rxb5 15. Ba3 Ra5 16. Rd3 Qb8 17. Rb3 Qc8 18. Qc3 Ra6 19. Qc4 Nd7 20. Rfb1 Rb6 21. f4 Rxb3 22. axb3 Nb6 23. Qf1 exf4 24. Qxf4 Qxh3 25. Rd1 Nc8 26. e5 Rd8 27. exd6 cxd6 28. Bxd6 Nxd6 29. c4 Nb7 30. Rxd8+ Nxd8 31. Qb8 Qd7 32. b4 Kf8 33. c5 Ke8 34. b5 a5 35. b6 Qb7
comment: ?? This loses by force! Again, ...Qd4+, 36. Kh1 Qxc5 37. b7 Qb5 wins for black.

moves: 1. b4 e5 2. Nc3 Bxb4 3. Bb2 Nf6 4. e4 Nc6 5. Nf3 O-O 6. g3 Nd4 7. Bg2 d6 8. O-O Bg4 9. h3 Nxf3+ 10. Bxf3 Bxf3 11. Qxf3 b5 12. Nxb5 Bxd2 13. Rad1 Rb8 14. Rxd2 Rxb5 15. Ba3 Ra5 16. Rd3 Qb8 17. Rb3 Qc8 18. Qc3 Ra6 19. Qc4 Nd7 20. Rfb1 Rb6 21. f4 Rxb3 22. axb3 Nb6 23. Qf1 exf4 24. Qxf4 Qxh3 25. Rd1 Nc8 26. e5 Rd8 27. exd6 cxd6 28. Bxd6 Nxd6 29. c4 Nb7 30. Rxd8+ Nxd8 31. Qb8 Qd7 32. b4 Kf8 33. c5 Ke8 34. b5 a5 35. b6 Qb7 36. Qe5+
comment:
? White could have had a beautiful win with 36. Qxb7 Nxb7 37. c6
Nc5 38. b7 Na6 39. c7!!, and black can't stop white from queening.
Chessplayers have this expression: "Two passed pawns on the 6th rank (row) are
worth a rook".

moves: 1. b4 e5 2. Nc3 Bxb4 3. Bb2 Nf6 4. e4 Nc6 5. Nf3 O-O 6. g3 Nd4 7. Bg2 d6 8. O-O Bg4 9. h3 Nxf3+ 10. Bxf3 Bxf3 11. Qxf3 b5 12. Nxb5 Bxd2 13. Rad1 Rb8 14. Rxd2 Rxb5 15. Ba3 Ra5 16. Rd3 Qb8 17. Rb3 Qc8 18. Qc3 Ra6 19. Qc4 Nd7 20. Rfb1 Rb6 21. f4 Rxb3 22. axb3 Nb6 23. Qf1 exf4 24. Qxf4 Qxh3 25. Rd1 Nc8 26. e5 Rd8 27. exd6 cxd6 28. Bxd6 Nxd6 29. c4 Nb7 30. Rxd8+ Nxd8 31. Qb8 Qd7 32. b4 Kf8 33. c5 Ke8 34. b5 a5 35. b6 Qb7 36. Qe5+ Ne6 37. Qd6 a4 38. c6 Qxb6+ 39. Kg2 Qc5 40. Qd7+ Kf8 41. Qc8+ Ke7 42. Qd7+ Kf6 43. g4 g5 44. Kf3 a3 45. Ke4 a2 46. Qd1 Qxc6+ 47. Ke3 Qa6
comment: This wins, but 47. ...Qc3+ 48. K moves a1(Q) would make white resign.
